newsitem.title: SPAIN: Jordan's Hussein counters Israeli blame for deaths.
newsitem.headline: Jordan's Hussein counters Israeli blame for deaths.

text.p: Jordan's King Hussein defended himself on Thursday against accusations by Israeli ministers that his warnings of violence had somehow led to the killings of seven schoolgirls by a Jordanian soldier.
Hussein had warned in a letter published on Wednesday there was a "very strong chance of violence" if Israel pushed ahead with plans for a Jewish settlement on the outskirts of Arab East Jerusalem.

"It was fully in my responsibility to warn that we have come too far," Hussein told journalists in Spain, referring to his letter to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, which has been criticised by Israeli officials.

Israel's Education Minister Zevulun Hammer suggested the Jordan king should not have spoken out about possible violence, telling army radio: "Perhaps the conclusion is that the king must hold his tongue so that a soldier doesn't take his words to mean more than he intended."
Hussein, who cut short a visit to Spain because of the killings, said he had never thought his words would be taken that way.
He added that he felt the peace he had worked for his whole life was facing a difficult moment.
Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy also made a reference to "gun-toting lunatics" waiting for an excuse, but he said he was not referring to Hussein's statement.
